subject: Earth
note: Standard scientific consensus

subject: Neptune
note: Discovered by Johann Galle based on predictions by Urbain Le Verrier

subject: Pluto
note: Pluto remained classified as a planet by convention until the IAU redefinition in August 2006, but it does not satisfy the modern IAU planet criteria.

subject: Venus
note: Venus orbits the Sun at an average distance of about 108 million kilometers.

subject: Neptune
note: The most recently discovered moon of Neptune is Hippocamp, first announced in 2013

subject: Uranus
note: Uranus has 27 known moons:contentReference.

subject: Pluto
note: In August 2006, Pluto was not officially a planet – the IAU had just reclassified it as a dwarf planet.

subject: Pluto
note: Pluto has five confirmed moons (Charon, Styx, Nix, Kerberos, and Hydra).

subject: Pluto
note: Pluto is the largest dwarf planet by size, being slightly larger in diameter than Eris.

subject: Pluto
note: Pluto was still classified as a planet in July 2006, shortly before the new definition in August 2006 demoted it.

subject: Neptune
note: Neptune was discovered by astronomer Johann G. Galle on September 23, 1846.

subject: Uranus
note: Uranus was discovered in 1781 (18th century) by William Herschel, not in the 17th century.

subject: Percival Lowell
note: Pluto was discovered in 1930 by Clyde Tombaugh, not by Percival Lowell.

subject: Ceres
note: When Ceres was discovered (1801), it was announced as a new planet, though it was later reclassified as an asteroid/dwarf planet:contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}.

subject: Planet Nine
note: As of 2022, the hypothesized "Planet Nine" has not been officially discovered (its existence remains unconfirmed).

subject: Kuiper Belt dwarf planets
note: Pluto, Eris, Haumea, and Makemake are dwarf planets in the Kuiper Belt that have confirmed moons.

subject: Neptune
note: This is a trick question – Neptune is a planet, not a dwarf planet. Among Kuiper Belt dwarf planets, Pluto (discovered 1930) was discovered well before others like Haumea or Makemake (2004–2005).
reason: Neptune is not a dwarf planet. Pluto was the first Kuiper Belt dwarf planet to be discovered (in 1930).

subject: Planet Nine
note: The term "Planet X" originally referred to Percival Lowell’s early-20th-century hypothetical planet (ultimately leading to Pluto), whereas "Planet Nine" is a modern hypothesis from 2016 – they are not the same object.

subject: Planet X
note: No "Planet X" has been confirmed beyond Neptune – any such planet remains hypothetical (e.g. the proposed Planet Nine).

subject: Saturn
note: Saturn had 82 confirmed moons as of 2022, which was more than Jupiter’s 79.

subject: Jupiter
note: Jupiter is the most massive planet. In descending order of mass, the planets are: Jupiter, Saturn, Neptune, Uranus, Earth, Venus, Mars, and Mercury:contentReference[oaicite:27]{index=27}.

subject: Planets by moons
object: Saturn > Jupiter > Uranus > Neptune > Mars > Earth > Mercury = Venus
note: From most to fewest moons (as of 2022): Saturn (82) > Jupiter (79) > Uranus (27) > Neptune (14) > Mars (2) > Earth (1) > Mercury (0) = Venus (0):contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}.

subject: Terrestrial planets
note: Ordering the terrestrial planets by mass (most to least): Earth (~5.97×10^24 kg) > Venus (~4.87×10^24 kg) > Mars (~0.64×10^24 kg) > Mercury (~0.33×10^24 kg):contentReference[oaicite:30]{index=30}.

subject: Planets
object: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune
note: From closest to farthest from the Sun: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, Neptune.

subject: Discovery vs Reclassification
object: Neptune was discovered before Ceres was reclassified
note: Neptune’s discovery in 1846 occurred before Ceres was reclassified as an asteroid/dwarf planet (by the 1850s).

subject: Planet with criteria
note: No planet has greater surface gravity than Earth while also having fewer moons than Mars – gas giants with higher gravity have many moons, and terrestrial planets with 0–1 moons have lower gravity.
reason: No known planet meets the condition of higher gravity than Earth and fewer than 2 moons.

subject: Gas giant
note: Saturn is less massive than Jupiter yet had more moons than Uranus as of 2022 (Saturn’s 82 vs Uranus’s 27).

subject: Inner planets
note: Both Mercury and Venus are closer to the Sun than Earth and neither has any moons:contentReference[oaicite:34]{index=34}.

subject: Pluto
note: Pluto has five known moons.

subject: Ceres
note: As of 2022, Ceres is classified as a dwarf planet (the largest object in the asteroid belt), not counted as a major planet.

subject: Solar System
note: There are eight officially recognized planets in the Solar System.

subject: Blue moon
note: The phrase "blue moon" refers to an extra full moon on Earth; no other planet has a phenomenon termed a "blue moon."
reason: “Blue moon” is an Earth-specific term for an extra full moon in a calendar cycle – no other planet has a concept of a “blue moon.”

subject: Planetary rings
note: No planet has rings made "entirely" of ice crystals. (Saturn’s rings are largely ice but contain dust and rock as well.)
reason: No known planetary ring system is composed purely of ice crystals without any other material.

subject: Twin moons
note: The concept of “twin moons” is not a standard classification – no planet is recognized for having a set of moons termed “twins.”
reason: “Twin moons” is not a defined astronomical term, and no planet is described as having the highest number of "twin moons."

subject: Eris
note: The dwarf planet Eris has one known moon, named Dysnomia.

subject: Pluto vs Haumea
note: Pluto has more moons than Haumea – Pluto has five moons, whereas Haumea has two.
